image.altText: Composite image of a main in a grey sweater with stock charts and cryptocurrency coins behind him.

items.synopsis: Blockchain Global promoted itself as the nation's biggest cryptocurrency exchange before its spectacular fall from grace. Now, a group of former customers are pursuing the company after losing access to their funds — with three of the company's key players being reported to ASIC by the liquidator.

title.children: The search for $50 million lost after Blockchain Global's crypto exchange collapse

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

items.synopsis: The transport minister says a request for her to front an inquiry examining the decision to reject Qatar Airways from expanding its services in Australia is a political stunt, and a waste of her time.

title.children: 'Time wasting': Transport minister rebuffs request to front airlines inquiry

image.altText: Protestors march the streets holding signs during a rally in Perth

items.synopsis: Former WA Mental Health Commissioner Tim Marney was let go after being contracted to implement a new model of care for juvenile detainees — and the Inspector of Custodial Services Eamon Ryan says he was just getting started.

title.children: 'Surprised and disappointed': Inspector of Custodial services wants to know why Banksia Hill reformer was let go

image.altText: A girl sits up in bed, hugging her knees to her chest. Her face is blurred by a sheet of tempered glass.

items.synopsis: Florence is among hundreds of Australians who have allegedly been sexually assaulted in mental health wards. As her parents consider legal action against the hospital, she wants her story told to keep others safe.

title.children: Teenage girl allegedly raped while being treated in Perth Children's Hospital mental health ward

image.altText: A US dollar note is pictured alongside an Australian 10 dollar and 20 dollar bill.

items.synopsis: Economists warn a significant fall in the Australian dollar will put further upwards pressure on inflation.

title.children: Australian dollar 'at risk' of falling into the 50s against the greenback

image.altText: Fitness coach Cass Olholm

items.synopsis: A company founded by Adelaide fitness superstar Kayla Itsines has taken a former employee to court, seeking to stop her from launching a rival fitness app.

title.children: Company founded by Kayla Itsines takes rival trainer to court over launch of fitness app

image.altText: A young person standing outside the Brisbane Magistrates court

items.synopsis: Drew Pavlou has vowed to never pay fines he received over a protest sign criticising Beijing, saying he will challenge them in a higher court.

title.children: 'Smart alec' activist fails in bid to overturn fines for sign mocking Chinese Communist Party

image.altText: A circle of rocks surrounding a hole in the ground in an outback paddock.

items.synopsis: Police say they are investigating the apparent desecration of the cultural heritage site, which has hurt and angered the area's Aboriginal custodians.

title.children: 'Another insult' as Indigenous well filled with concrete in outback Queensland

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Gorgon gas project on the coast of Western Australia.

items.synopsis: Australia may be a quarry to the world, and the mining of its natural resources might underpin our national budget. But we can and must demand better corporate ethics than this, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A 'sham' workforce in WA has exposed the shadowy ways of global oil and gas — and workers are paying the price

image.altText: Kemuel Tamwoy sits in from of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags

items.synopsis: Indigenous leaders in Cape York and the Gulf say the Voice to Parliament can make a difference, provided it has strong grassroots participation.

title.children: 'It's got to be someone local': How some Indigenous leaders want the Voice to operate

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The federal Labor minister was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease during her first pregnancy and says, like others with invisible diseases, she does not want people drawing their own conclusions about her illness.

title.children: Why Anika Wells doesn't publicly name her chronic illness

image.altText: Illustration of Australia with night sky and stars in background and yellow circle in middle of Australia.

items.synopsis: On October 14, every Australian will be asked to answer a yes or no question. What you write on the ballot paper will determine whether our constitution is changed for the first time in more than four decades. Here's everything you need to know before you vote.

title.children: Your Voice voting cheat sheet: All your referendum questions, answered

image.altText: A Melbourne Demons ruckman smiles as he talks to a teammate (whose back is turned to the camera) after a win.

items.synopsis: Melbourne midfielder James Harmes says he and ruckman Brodie Grundy, who are both likely to seek AFL trades, grew close as they dealt with being frozen out.

title.children: Frozen-out Demons Harmes and Grundy lean on each other as trades loom

image.altText: A speed sign on the side of a country road. Its numerals have been altered with tape so that it reads "No".

items.synopsis: Speed signs altered to read "No" have been spotted in SA, sparking safety concerns and a police investigation.

title.children: Multiple speed signs defaced as early voting for the Voice gets underway

image.altText: Two people sit on a stage smiling, both wearing t-shirts that say Vote No to the Voice of Division

items.synopsis: More than 1,000 vocal No supporters are urged by Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Nyunggai Warren Mundine not to get complacent ahead of the historic referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Price and Mundine issue rallying cry to No crowd in Perth as Voice vote draws closer

image.altText: Sue Hedley holding grey cat with crates behind

items.synopsis: A rescue group calls for Qantas to reconsider its animal flight rules, with concerns more could be euthanased in WA's Pilbara.

title.children: Rescue group fears animals will be put down if Qantas sticks to heat rules

image.altText: Tall plumes of white and dark blue smoke seen rising above houses and trees on top of a hill at Bermagui in NSW

items.synopsis: A bushfire is impacting properties on the New South Wales South Coast and authorities expect the challenging conditions to continue into the night.

title.children: Residents told it's too late to leave as bushfires rage in NSW

image.altText: Close up of faces of a man and his adult son wearing bike helmets on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: Ed Croft, who testified before the disability royal commission, says his son experienced significant problems in mainstream schooling and parents need to be able to choose.

title.children: 'Their only solution was to lock him in a cupboard': Dad dismayed by royal commission recommendation to close special schools

image.altText: Melbourne Demons AFLW player Libby Birch has a look of concentration after executing a handball in a game

items.synopsis: AFLW player Libby Birch wants more women to feel comfortable talking about their breasts, while more options are now available to help those playing contact sport avoid injury.

title.children: Finding the right fit: Why breasts are a still a 'taboo' topic in sport, and what we can do to protect them

image.altText: A young woman in a fluoro vest with pink glasses standing between trains.

items.synopsis: Chelsea Taylor thought university was the only option after school. But after three unfinished degrees and $30,000 in student debt, she felt "really, really lost" — until she became a train driver.

title.children: After racking up a big student debt, Chelsea became a train driver. She says career advice is limiting teenagers

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair cries while sitting in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Biannca Edmunds has been sentenced to 26 years' jail after a botched assassination plan she hatched with her husband, targeting her ex-partner, resulted in both men's deaths.

title.children: Judge says woman showed 'extreme' entitlement by plotting to kill her ex-partner over custody issues

image.altText: Split screen image of a woman and a man on ABC's Q+A.

items.synopsis: As Senator Malarndirri McCarthy reveals the moment she felt most "disempowered", a debate focused on who the Voice will help takes over Q+A.

title.children: 'Disadvantage' locked into the constitution or 'significant moment'? Voice debate heats up on Q+A

image.altText: An elderly woman skydiving with a man.

items.synopsis: Dorothy Hoffner did her dive on Sunday in Chicago, hoping to claim the title once owned by late South Australian woman Irene O'Shea.

title.children: Chicago woman, 104, skydives aiming for record of world's oldest skydiver — a title once held by an Australian woman

image.altText: Composite image of two photos of a man - a selfie with him smoking a cigar and a mugshot. Around him are passport stamps.

items.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: This Australian is sitting in a foreign prison cell. He's ready to come clean about his life undercover

image.altText: Kacey and Layne stand together smiling on a suburban street.

items.synopsis: Less than half of the federal government's promised urgent care clinics have opened, months after the policy was supposed to be delivered.

title.children: After waiting six hours in an emergency department, Kasey is wondering where her city's Urgent Care Clinic is

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: A District Court Civil Judge has granted an application to prevent an Adelaide woman accused of murdering her parents from accessing their estate.

title.children: Woman accused of killing parents denied access to their estate

image.altText: high school with fence

items.synopsis: A female student has been charged after a male student was transported to hospital in a stable condition following an alleged violent altercation involving a knife at Caloundra State High School.

title.children: Sunshine Coast high school goes into lockdown as alleged knife incident puts student in hospital

image.altText: A blonde, bespectacled woman and two men in suits walk down a city street.

items.synopsis: Nicole Louise Bourne was charged with more than 200 offences in 2020. Today, just as a six-day trial was to begin, she has pleaded guilty to 39 charges.

title.children: Magistrate furious over 'outrageous' waste of time after 11th-hour plea from pet store owner

image.altText: nsw police at a crime scene where a woman was found inside a home in Bankstown

items.synopsis: Police allege the 31-year-old man stabbed his mother to death, killed her cat and set the family home on fire in Sydney's south west.

title.children: Son allegedly killed mother a day after being granted bail for attacking her, court told

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in court and looks straight ahead. The gallery behind him is full of people.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump is fighting a civil lawsuit that could cost him control of his prized properties and his freedom to do business in New York. Here's what happened on day one of the trial.

title.children: Trump's fraud case could cost him $327m and the jewel in his real estate crown. Here's how it's unfolding

image.altText: A woman, covering her head in a blanket, sits looking upward, surrounded by barbed wire

items.synopsis: Several hundred migrants in southern Mexico wait for buses to the country's north in a new government program meant to help manage the number of people entering the country.

title.children: Mexico sends buses to collect migrants as thousands reach US border

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

items.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear
